title: Blast Lung Injury Severity Score
description: Stratifies primary blast lung injuries into three severity categories to guide ventilatory treatment and predict clinical outcomes

parameters.name: pao2_fio2_ratio
parameters.description: PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio in mmHg - key indicator of oxygenation status

parameters.name: chest_xray_findings
parameters.description: Chest X-ray findings indicating extent of pulmonary infiltrates
options: bilateral_or_unilateral - Bilateral or unilateral lung infiltrates (1 point)
massive_bilateral - Massive bilateral lung infiltrates (2 points)

parameters.name: bronchial_pleural_fistula
parameters.description: Presence of bronchial pleural fistula - abnormal connection between airways and pleural space
options: no - No bronchial pleural fistula (0 points)
yes - Bronchial pleural fistula present (1 point)

result.name: blast_lung_injury_score
result.description: Blast lung injury severity score for risk stratification and treatment guidance

ranges.interpretation: Mild blast lung injury with excellent prognosis. ARDS risk: ~0%, Mortality: ~0%. Recommended ventilation: Volume-controlled or pressure support ventilation. PEEP: ≤5 cm H₂O. Standard respiratory monitoring and supportive care.

Moderate blast lung injury with intermediate risk. ARDS risk: 33%, Mortality: ~0%. Recommended ventilation: Conventional modes, consider inverse-ratio ventilation if needed. PEEP: 5-10 cm H₂O. Close respiratory monitoring required.

Severe blast lung injury with poor prognosis. ARDS risk: 100%, Mortality: 75%. Recommended ventilation: Conventional modes with potential advanced therapies. PEEP: >10 cm H₂O. Consider nitric oxide, high-frequency jet ventilation, independent lung ventilation, or ECMO.

references: Pizov R, Oppenheim-Eden A, Matot I, Weiss YG, Eidelman LA, Rivkind AI, et al. Blast lung injury from an explosion on a civilian bus. Chest. 1999 Jan;115(1):165-72.

Leibovici D, Gofrit ON, Stein M, Shapira SC, Noga Y, Heruti RJ, et al. Blast injuries: bus versus open-air bombings--a comparative study of injuries in survivors of open-air versus confined-space explosions. J Trauma. 1996 Dec;41(6):1030-5.
Wolf SJ, Bebarta VS, Bonnett CJ, Pons PT, Cantrill SV. Blast injuries. Lancet. 2009 Jul 18;374(9687):405-15.
formula: Sum of points from 3 components: PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio (0-2 points) + Chest X-ray findings (0-2 points) + Bronchial pleural fistula (0-1 point). Total score range: 0-5 points
notes: Developed specifically for primary blast lung injury (PBLI) from high-intensity pressure waves
Most effective when applied within 2 hours of blast injury
Score primarily used for patients with respiratory symptoms after blast exposure
Helps guide respiratory management decisions and predict clinical outcomes
Mild (0 points): Excellent prognosis, standard supportive care
Moderate (1-4 points): 33% ARDS risk, requires close monitoring and conventional ventilation
Severe (5 points): 100% ARDS risk, 75% mortality, may require advanced respiratory support
Advanced therapies for severe cases include nitric oxide, HFJV, independent lung ventilation, ECMO
PEEP recommendations: Mild ≤5 cm H₂O, Moderate 5-10 cm H₂O, Severe >10 cm H₂O
Consider lung-protective ventilation strategies similar to ARDS management
Monitor for complications including pneumothorax, air embolism, and hemoptysis
Score was developed and validated in military and civilian blast injury populations
